titleStmt.title: M112, set 1 of 3 [The Reader: manner brings in suggestions that give it another meaning]. Typescript fragment with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 4 fols.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M112, set 1 of 3 [The Reader: manner brings in suggestions that give it another meaning]. Typescript fragment with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 4 fols.
p. 33 with fragment paginated p. 30 on verso.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p: But again down on the the curtain rises. The trumpets sound; the flag blows and the shadowy insubstantial life txmxmxx of Squires, nobles Maids of hnour (honour) and country gentlmen (gentlemen) is before us. In one second we are in the thick of love; murder; adultery. is before us. There is and his ; there is the adulterere (adulterer); and the villain. Supper is laid; the cards are on the table, and next moment the husband throwing open the door sees his wife lying in the arms of her lover. The yellow pages in Record offices and Muniments rooms wit (with) their contorsions (contortions), their evasions, give place to outright speech. In the play tself (itself) all is evident, outapoken (outspoken). In r al (real) life all is shadowy and suppressed.

But by degrrees (degrees) the dramatist sheds his anonymity. He separates himself from his audience. He pauses, sometimes; he di erts (diverts) the interest from the action to the mtove (motive) motive behind the action. What, he broods in , is the effect of mercy?--- if the adulters are confronted not with death but with a guilty conscience? As the plays come faster and faster, as the curtain rises again and again, upon , , , , -- anonymity and the pressure of the audience cease to bind the playwright. The reader loses his anonymity too. He chhoses (chooses); he discrimitaes (discriminates). Here are
kick nacks (knicknacks); curiosities; illustrations of the time. But here on the other hand, what we call for short ourselves-- the thought that we think instcintively (instinctively), the comment that

manner brings in suggestions that give it another meaning almost. the word suggests often the manner of the clothes. We cannot shut out the contrast often between the past and the present. And as the habit of reading becomes universal many varities (varieties) of reader split off. There are the specilaised (specialised) readers whose power of drawing out the meaning of words is tremendously developed; so that remain attached to certain aspects of the rinted (printed) page; the scholars, the sudents (students). Agaian (Again) there is the very large vlass (class) of perfectly literate people whoruns (who run) who run their eyes over miles of print yet never read a word. The reader at the moment is probably the [illeg.] reader. When the reader proper, with his power to m kae (make)
ouses (houses) and countries visible, men and women and their though (thoughts) and emotions from marks on a ice (piece) eof (of) paper bec came into existence it is difficult to say. He is always
chnaging (changing). The is now develpoing (developing) his eye. The is developing his ear. The fate if (of) literature of course is in his hands. But Axxxhe He is still is still apparently reading

One reason why is still read is simply the inadequacy of Shakespriean (Shakespearean) cri cism (criticism). The inadequacy of that criticism is means that is due of course to the it is always autobiographical criticism. xxxxxxxxxxxxx It is a comm nplace (commonplace) tp (to) say that every critic finds his own features in Shakepare (Shakespeare). His variety is such that every one wxxxx can find scattered here or there the [that which?] he can develop ent (development) of some one of his own attrbutes (attributes). The critic then accents what is he is responsive to, and so composes his own meaning, in Shakesperes (Shakespeare's) words. The S. the S. the S.

that of the , the Cxmxmxxxx , the the and above all the Cliffo ds (Cliffords) has become like a precious stone not to be mized (mixed) with baser metal. When Lord marries
ifit (it) was "held a very mean match an indiscreet on (indiscretion) on part of him" She believss (believes) in the immortality of the body as firmly as in the immortality of the soul.

Yet there were moments when even this carapace of possessions proved too heavy for her; when on the first day xmxmxmxmmxmxx If I had not excellent book
here to comfort me, I were in a pitiable case, having so many troubles as I have here, but when I read in that, I nscorn (scorn) and make light of them all, and a little part of his beauteous spirit infuses itself in me."
She adds that postcriot (postscript) wxmxmxmxmxmx to a letter about a little cabinet and cup which she had left with Lady when she borrowed a hundred pounds of her.

But it is only when she reads that she comments. When she goes to the play she says only "Supped with my Lord and Lady and after supper
OI (I) saw the play of the Mad Lover..." or "We stood to see the Masque in the box with my Lady " It was when the playhouses were shut presumably that the reader was born. xmxmxmxmxmxmxm The cur us (curious) faculty of making houses and countries
visble (visible), and men and women and their emotions, from marks on a printed page was undevleoped (undeveloped) as

so long as the play was domenant (dominant). The audience at the
plahouse (playhouse) had to draw in the play with their eyes and ears. Without a book of the words they could not deepen and revive the impression left by the play, or ask those questions that are debated daily now in every newspaper. The lack of generl (general)
r ading (reading) acconts (accounts) for the long pause between Sahkespsreas (Shakespeare's) death and the i8th (18th) centiry (century) when the plays of Shakespre (Shakespeare) hung suspended unreaslied (unrealised). Even in 17 - could say that Shakespere (Shakespeare) still lacked half his proper fame. It accojts (accounts) too for the scarcity of criticism, and for the general nature of what critisim (criticism) there was. Both and are writing for the s ll ([small? still?]) critical public, and thus deal general questions andnot (and not) with
partciularities (particularities) and personalitties (personalities). Mxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxe mxmxmmxmxmxmxmmmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmmxmx primxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxy xmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmx

A life history of the reader during the past four hundred years would be needed disocver (discover) at what point he lost the acuten ss (acuteness) of his eyes; of his ears. at what point he
devloped (developed) he (the) power of asscoation (association); so that now a word printed in the old spelling suggests a thosand (thousand) a

The biographer of the reader during the past four hundred years w uld (would) discover at what point his ear lost its acuteness; when his ey d (eyes) became dull; when to balance this loss, he became cosncious (conscious) of suggestions and echoes, and as time passed added much that was unintended by the wxmxmxx writer. It would show that

we lost much whe (when) the p spectator was transfomed (transformed) into the read (reader) the sound of the spoeken (spoken) word; a thousand suggestions that the dramtist (dramatist) conveys b (by) gestures, by grouping and the inflection of the voice. as if alone that proved by the the effort we make in reading the earky (early) plays to supply the trumpets and the flags, the citizens and the apprenetices (apprentices). And in attempting this fthe (the) reader is perpetually baffled; He is apt to become not a reader, but a st dent (student); and as his reading power develops, and as the habit of reading becomes universal, there split off the specilaised (specialised) readers with their tremendously developed power of ddrawing (drawing) o (out) the meaning of words; and again the very large class of perfectly literate people who though they strip many miles of pint (print) yearly from paper mever (never) read a word; and finally the reader, who like Lady , read excellent book when they are in trouble, "and a little part of his beautoeus (beauteous) spirit infuses itself in me." And the reader is always changing, The cimea (cinema) is now develpping (developing) his eyes; the Braod (Broadcast) cast is develpoing (developing) his ear. He is still causing books to be printed His imprtance can be gausged (gauged) by the act that when his attention is distracted, in times of public crisis, the writer exclaims: I cannot write any more. I have no audience.
